newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity settles lower, weather moderate.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity settles lower, weather moderate.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures fell in a retracement from last week's run-up amid moderate weather in much of the U.S. West, market sources said Monday.
"The market was pretty boring. We saw a retracement off of low volume," said one dealer.

Barring a significant pick-up in natural gas prices, which could happen if gas is drawn up amid the heatwave afflicting the East Coast, the NYMEX electricity complex may remain rangebound this week, he added.
The July California Oregon Border (COB) contract settled down $1.16 per megawatt hour (MWh) at $20.34 following trade at $20.25-$20.80.
August COB ended 82 cents lower at $23.19 per MWh, while September settled down 50 cents at $23.00.
July Palo Verde (PV) closed down $1.19 at $32.71, after trading between $32.40 and $33.00.
August PV lost $1.16 to settle at $33.90, while September PV fell 70 cents to settle at $28.80.
Temperatures in the Southwest were forecast to average between zero and five degrees F below normal through mid-week, rising to near normal to above normal by the end of the month.
Northwest temperatures were forecast at four to eight degrees below normal through mid-week, rising to above normal by next week.
The NYMEX July Henry Hub natural gas contract gained 1.1 cents to settle at $2.246 per million British thermal units.

Separately, the Western Systems Coordinating Council (WSCC) committee last week recommended a the Pacific Intertie transmission system be derated from July 1-30 to 6,300 MW from the current limit of 7,200 MW.
The WSCC board is expected to approve the plan this week.
As of 1535 PDT, NYMEX estimated 400 COB and 442 PV contractswere traded.
